commentBody: Later-week puzzles have been so good lately. Nice one!

TRADE WARS? What TRADE WARS?

HO HO. LIVE LARGE.

FEARSOME? 1A! (emu avoidance).

Nice one, Katie.

Speaking of DOOK, 
after I started the puzzle 
but before I finished, 
was I AMIDONE?

As many of you know, I moved last Wednesday for the first time in 40 years, and the Mrs. and I have been unpacking and fixing things up for the past ten days, but today was an especially busy day, with a water heater issue, our handyman's last scheduled visit to take care of a few last minute issues, and some later-stage unpacking going on at the same time.

By 6:30, everyone was done, and I settled in for a sandwich for dinner and then the Mets game.  I was quite exhausted, but managed to wind down nicely by 10:00.

Still, when I started doing this puzzle, I wasn't vibing with the clues, and the entire NW and SE looked like a big blank. 31 Down!  I tell everyone that experienced puzzlers face each puzzle with a "when, not if" attitude (about reaching a clean solve), but five minutes into the puzzle, I started to wonder whether that clean solve might have to come after a full night's sleep!

Well, 1 Across!

Little by little, things came to me, and I meandered around the puzzle until everything fit in and made sense, more or less, without a single 27 Down, and then it was 55 Across!

And a quick look at my stats showed that I actually finished about a minute and a quarter faster than my Saturday average.

Tons of unknowns made this one seem FEARSOME to me and TONS of the clues seemed to be stretches, so I was surprised to finish this one in a reasonable time.  I was helped by the fact that one of the arcane clues (ALEC Bohm) was up my alley as a Phillies fan, and in fact I had the Phillies game on while solving.  It was one of a very few toeholds I got on my pass through the acrosses.  However, that’s a pretty obscure reference, and I’ll understand if people want to gripe about it.
What a workout. Fair, but tough. Just how I like my Saturday puzzles. "King me" was a particularly enjoyable aha moment. This puzzle pushed my current streak to 1400, and I had to fight for it.

Just stopping by to say I GOTTA JET!

More details maybe to come, as I LIVE LARGE in London.
Excellent puzzle. It was a challenge but I learned some interesting things with this one.

The intersection of
MENOMOSSO
IGOTTAJET (which I had as IGOTToJET)
HAJIS
STAVE
and
TARO
was a few too many Naticks for me.

Tough, tough tough! 35 minutes of pure grinding. Some things that tripped me up were nBA instead of ABA, IGOTTArun instead of IGOTTAJET. But the real kicker was realizing the answer was WELD, not some kind of romantic reunion or sExt

I loved, loved, loved this puzzle.  Fantastic clueing.
I had a I GOTTA GET/HAGIS at the end and was pulling my hear out.
SE Corner bested me.

E.T. wants an iced latte to foam home.

(He needs a cup for his saucer.)

Wow—I finished this but haven’t the faintest idea how. Actually well under my Saturday average, but probably about average for my current skill level. I had a few bits and pieces here and there, and lot of guessing and looking for letter patterns. Every corner seemed to be pulling teeth and closed off, with either a lot of personal Naticks (SE) or just ambiguous clues that just seemed hard to handle. I truly enjoyed a lot of the clues— TRADE WARS and “original plot” for EDEN—but some seemed a little unfair and just seemed to be more mean than clever—Secure over? Shouldn’t that be “secure over again?” Charcoal and wood? Sure wood can be a medium but so is tinfoil and Apple Jacks for that matter. (Ok I suppose wood’s more common than either of them and I did just visit the Met and that was most of  the Oceania exhibits, so I suppose…) Kate and Allie? That takes me back but that’s a pretty big stretch even for an old fogey like myself. Still, I can take satisfaction that I pulled it out but no complaining tonight about too easy, I think?
Now that was a Saturday puzzle requiring persistence and perseverance.  WOW.
Was confused by 13D, “hair of the dog” wouldn’t fit and down this way there is no chance beer would ever get stale…
absolutely loved this one!  Challenging to wrestle with, and very satisfying when I was finally done.  Thank you!

Brutal. 




Do you agree, emus?

A real challenge.  One that I couldn't meet.

Just too many uncertain entries to be able to really focus on one.

In the end, I was done in by insisting on IGOTTAgET.  I have never heard of "I gotta jet".  That was my only mistake when I folded and checked the whole puzzle.

I don't know if I fell short with a really tough puzzle, or a easy one, as my hard-o-meter is in the shop.

Looking now in the comments to see which.

Ironically, the first fill I got was “no me gusto,” porque me gusta el crucigrama!

Buenas noches..
One of the harder Saturdays of the year by my reckoning. Fun, long solve!

Just 30 days ago, there was quite a backlash against I BEEN HAD

A few defended that answer with caveats; I was just about the only one who did so resolutely.

I expect I GOTTA JET will engender similar opprobrium today - unless, in the interim, y'all have come around to my point of view.
Long, looong time since an NYT crossword put up a fight like that

What can I say, Katie?  Your puzzle was  FEARSOMEly, relentlessly tough.  I had so many blanks for so long I didn't think I would ever be able to finish it, but with the help of some intuitive, improbable guesses, and two successful and one unsuccessful look-ups, I did.  MEGUSTó it a lot!

Thank you for giving us a memorable puzzle.
This one was not for me. Not a fun solve.

At no moment was I even remotely close to solving this unaided. All I had after several across and down passes were nine entries, two or three of which turned out to be wrong later.

I googled most of the proper names, trivia and the like: STLEO, ARI, ALEC, POLS, ABA, TED, OSMIC, NO ME GUSTA, TKO. This helped - I completed 3/4 of the puzzle then. Still, the SE corner was empty. In the end I needed reveals to deal with it. MENOMOSSO looks totally alien to me. I GOTTA... JET? After nearly 40 years of learning English I can't recall ever seeing or hearing that. I had "run" there. Components of sweet tea are... Tea and sugar. I know of TARO but I've never seen it as a tea ingredient.

Unknown stuff I got from crosses was plentiful, too: MOTHERS (the clue is a mystery), ECHOISM, and the mysterious CSA - what is that? Of course it's not cheap Vered by the column.

TRADE WAR I got instantly, and was annoyed by how it reminded me of the sorry state of the modern world, a playground 

CRIMP, to me, a climber, is only a small, usually sharp hold on a climbing wall.

I was proud of remembering RECTO from a previous puzzle.

I guess this was a proper Saturday grid. I don't enjoy being defeated though so personally I didn't like it, but that's probably a "me" problem.
Tough but great
55A and 46D just for starters.  I really disliked this puzzle.

Very hard to break into, but this didn’t feel unfair. I eventually managed to conquer the SE unaided without having the faintest clue on “meno mosso”, so I wouldn’t rush to cry natick. Glad I stuck it out. Great puzzle!
completed only by the grace of at least six fourth-down-and-long hail-mary crosses.  (no reference to 1D consciously intended.)

I loved the Saturday challenge of it. 
I hated that I wasn’t Saturday solver enough to gold star it. 


It’s never a good sign when the only entry you can fill in on the first pass is NOMEGUSTA. And I don’t even speak Spanish!

While I had some holes in every corner. The NW was just a huge section of blank. Minus WELD and OPS. Getting TSELIOT from just the T in his last name was probably the highlight of my solve.  

I was really feeling myself the last couple months regarding Friday and Saturday.  This week just made me rethink life choices.  

But thank you Katie

Vicious, but excellent. Loved the fill and the clueing. The SE corner was daunting, and I was sweating bullets inputting my last letter, hoping beyond hope I had it right because I did not relish the idea of hunting for mistakes! Luckily, it all worked out in a little over my Saturday average.

I GOTTA JET was my favorite, simply because it's so dastardly. I struggled with I GOT To run for the longest time, until finally trying I GOTTA run. That A was just enough for things to click in my brain.

I hadn't done puzzles for a while until about six weeks ago. This was my first Saturday puzzle. I'm glad to read through all the comments and find that almost all commenters found this one particularly challenging.

I ventured this as a learning project. I looked up lots of things that I could Google. And also used the "check" and "reveal" options. It's sort of like playing Scrabble using the dictionary--still fun.

I learned a lot of things. Kate and Allie was a show I had never seen--about two divorced mothers who moved in together to lighten the load. I also found out a lot about the Clay/Liston fight and its controversial aftermath. And I finally learned what a technical knockout is. And how it differs from a Technical Decision. Very interesting. Also, a little bit about how you make a bow--with a stave!
Took me 33 minutes, and for all but the last few seconds of that I was unsure if I’d actually finish unaided. Great Saturday puzzle. Two thumbs up, WAY up!

I apparently have too little brain power and too much grit... It took me 78 minutes of grinding to solve this without any Internet help.   Ouch!  The worst was getting started, and then the southeast corner was a bear to finish on the end.
Perfect Saturday puzzle. King me !

Excellent throwback to the pre-Covid puzzle era (I still get stumped by older Fri and Sat puzzles from the Archives). The SE corner completely destroyed my self confidence and just that section took me 30min to crack. Time for a tub of chocolate ice cream to soothe my ego.
Well my comment was apparently rejected because my opinion after finishing the puzzle was 1a.  Just over my average time so not terribly difficult but a few wild goose chases.

Oof that was tough! I loved it. Including IGOTTAJET. It's not in everyone's vocabulary, but I say it a lot. It's maybe 90s slang? It reminds me of Dope Wars, a favorite game I had on possibly my Palm Pilot. The player is a drug dealer in NYC, navigating the boroughs, buying low, selling high, avoiding the fuzz. One action was JET, which moved the player somewhere else to check out the scene. Great fun, I remember sitting on a barstool and playing it.

@Caitlyn
If it's not too late to fix a typo in the article, surely you mean TRADE WARS. The singular form is a letter short.

This puzzle seemed very nuanced and playful to me. There was a constant tension between relatively straightforward clues and answers (23A Special OPS,  16A Verso's counterpoint, 57A Big names, as examples for me) and misdirects, word plays and tough answers, often unsignposted (4D, Original plot/EDEN, for instance).

And the idiomatic answers really modulated between almost slang (SCREW THAT, RECKON SO, I GOTTA JET and AM I DONE), and more elevated language (I AM AT A LOSS).

The overall effect, for me, was a delightful sense of imbalance, of never being able to be quite sure whether an apparently obvious answer was correct. Really enjoyable and playful.  Thanks  to Ms. Hoody, and to Will as always!

Weirdly I had no problem with the bottom half of this. Got the SW without much issue, then the SE. Struggled from there and spent half the solve time on the NW that I just couldn’t parse. Google came to my aid a bit, and some of the forum here, and the article for TRADE WARS, but I was getting nowhere by myself. Still not sure what some of the answers mean, so it may be one of those occasions on which a lack of transatlantic literacy is to blame…
Finished it but didn't feel any joy solving this puzzle, unfortunately. Well, there's always tomorrow.

NOMEGUSTA. Nice and challenging at first but six (6) random phrases (including one in Spanish)? One or two of them might be fixed expressions, like IMATALOSS, but the rest are just random things people might say. Why is that even puzzle-worthy? Add in a bunch of stuff I've never heard of, some truly weird cluing (chicken feed vis à vis breastfeed??), and two entries where the clue and the answer are in different registers ("commencement" is formal English, GETGO is the opposite), and it takes the fun out of it for me. And then there's the just plain incorrect: HOG isn't keeping to oneself, it's keeping *for* oneself. 

Before others can pounce, let me point out this is strictly my own opinion.

There were some worthwhile words and a few gems, like TSELIOT, but the questionable entries brought me down. SPIDERMAN almost saved the day but even he couldn't quite spin it.
The ‘O’ in TARO was the last to fall for me, even though given all the time I spent in Taiwanese bubble teas shops while at uni, it should’ve been second 奶茶.

I really didn't understand how the confederacy was a farmer's market alternative, but shoved that "CSA" in there anyway. 
(I see what it really is from a comment below - thanks for that, as I had never heard of those.)

What a perfect puzzle.  I just took a photo and placed it in my POY folder.

There were TONS of vague clues and things I had to figure out, making for a worthy Saturday challenge.  Just the way I like it.

Trivia heaviness often spoils Saturday puzzles for me, and today was just one of those Saturdays. 

I much prefer word-play where answers can be sussed out. But if you don't know trivia answers, especially if they cross multiple other trivia answers or foreign language phrases, there's just no moving forward. And if I need to start looking up answers, then I've lost the fun of solving.

At least I've been doing these puzzles long enough to know that some are just not for me. Looking forward to Sunday's puzzle!

What a lot of people said. Challenging, clever, a bit obscure sometimes.

I was surprised at 1A, and I'm assuming (given this is the NYT) the term isn't seen as quite offensive as in the UK? Thinking of a word beginning with f as a synonym.

Quite a few terms I'd never heard of, like HOLE CARDS, OSMIC, ECHOISM, TARO and the slang expressions.

Appropriate 15 letter answer that dawned on me this morning was: KATIEBARTHEDOOR Yeah, it's been an answer in two puzzles. Anyway - was not successful at today's puzzle. No complaints - that's all on me. So.. one unusual puzzle find today. A Sunday from June 10, 2001 by the great Cathy Allis with the title: "Basketry." I won't bother with the clues, but here are some of the theme answers: IFIHADAHAMPER TWINEANDDINE NOPAINNOCANE WEAVESOFGRASS WHATAMESH Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/10/2001&g=39&d=A Might put another puzzle in a reply. ....

Oh thank God everyone found this one challenging. I was quite defeated by it, couldn't get a foothold at all. Like Caitlin said, it was a throwback to when I first started doing Saturday puzzles. Haven't struggled this much in a while. Finally folded and looked up the tough clues in the column. Then clicked on comments thinking that if everyone here was talking about how easy it was, I would just cry 😂😂

Slow going almost all the way. I GOTTA JET? Nope, never. I gotta run. HOLE CARDS? Never heard of it. STALE BEER? Had plenty of occasions to need the hair of the dog in my younger days, but I was never a beer drinker, so hard pass on that one. Yet another obscure basball player atop another sports clue? And an obscure musical term - MENOMOSSO? I only know STAVE from barrels, not bows, so even getting SMOKE RINGS didn't help. In the NE, even knowing AMISH, RECTO and IDEAL didn't help either. That side and SE were my undoing. 

I like a tough Saturday when I find that all the hard work results in success. This was not one of them. Just too much arcane trivia.

My first answer, NO ME GUSTA, was a gimme, since I was a Spanish teacher. I had no clue it was going to be the opposite of Love, love, love for me and this puzzle.

Honestly felt like just a bunch of inside jokes and references between Ms Hoody and herself mixed with a bunch of the most obscure Google search results. Finished in decent time, but absolutely joyless.

Holy moly.  What a talent.  Five puzzles into the Times, and Katie has shot into my top-tier group of constructors.  When I saw her name atop the blank grid, I actually yessed with a fist pump.  Her offering today once again, with its wit, play, and skill, once again brought me to the height of solving joy.

Joy – this grid design, which calmed and relaxed me even before filling in my first square.  Grid design is often a non-factor in a puzzle, but Katie has made it an asset in most of her puzzles.  Today, the relaxed feeling it elicited made me feel like I was solving with Procol Harum’s “A Whiter Shade of Pale” in the background.

Joy – Beautiful and interesting answers.  LIVE LARGE, RECKON SO, LURK, MENO MOSSO, I’M AT A LOSS, NO ME GUSTA, RATS NEST, KING ME.

Joy – OMG, the cluing.  A riddle-fest.  Misdirects, wordplays, “Hah!” producers all around the grid, such as [Free of typos, say] for EMEND, [Keep to oneself] for HOG, and [Rare showbiz collections] for EGOTS.

Joy – The master-level skill behind this.  Four gorgeous stacks in a low wordcount, low block grid, and no junky answers!  

More, more, more, I ask of you, Katie.  You bring such pleasure into solving.  Thank you!

Tough one. Loved some of the clever cluing; was I'll say "irritated" at some of the obscurities, which have already been hashed over by everyone else.  Bottom line, though, is we occasionally need a stumper like this. I'd turn into Narcissus if I had a steady diet of Krappy puzzles.

Crossword superstar Paolo Pasco Jeopardy watch, day eight.

All good things must come to an end, and Paolo lost to a strong opponent, but what a lovely run Paolo had, and he’ll be back for the Tournament of Champions, because any contestant who has won five games goes.  

He represented Crosslandia admirably.  At one point I went to a Jeopardy fan site, and commenters overwhelmingly praised  his smarts and demeanor.

It was fun to have a crossworder on the show, and I look forward to seeing him again in the TOC.  Go Paolo!

If you haven't heard of an OSMIC acid stain, don't despair--I'm not an expert in the field by any means, but I've spent dozens of hours taking pictures on an electron microscope, and it was new to me as well!

Fun but tough, tough but fair.  Glad that seems to be the consensus!  Usually with a grid like this, there's one corner that gives me trouble--this time it was all of them.
Agree that it was challenging but disagree that the clues were trivia or obscure. They were just hard! Just because you don't know something doesn't make it obscure!
After reading some comments I am ridiculously proud of solving this one. Took some time and many wrong guesses, but I got there.
Tough but still fun. As a mechanical engineer and hobbyist welder, I appreciated 5 Down "Connect with a flame," even though most WELDing these days is done with an electric arc. Great clue, though!
First time I had to give in and look up an answer in weeks..whew..a real Saturday puzzle!
Could not get a hold of this one. Needed lots of help. Still so much fun. Great cluing - just not in my wheelhouse today. Have a great Saturday, y’all! Thanks, Katie! And, Wordplay for the help!

Found this one rather easy, and solved it without assistance, though it took me about 35 minutes. I'm not a fast solver like some here. Some of the clues were very clever---"Connect with a flame" for WELD and "Hidden assets" for HOLECARDS, for example. Wasn't familiar with MENOMOSSO or ECHOISM, and got those largely from the crosses. IGOTTARUN and IGOTTAFLY before IGOTTAJET slowed me down in the SE.

Enjoyable Saturday puzzle, though the grid geometry had me feeling at times like I was solving rather disconnected mini-puzzles in the four corners of the grid.

I love Saturdays.
Thank you!

My original post last night was emu’d once again. I basically said that it was defeating me. I had the south section of the grid finished, but I was tired from traveling most of the day to Flagstaff for parents weekend, and I GOTTA JET to bed to continue in the morning. After ruminating on the grid in my sleep, the rest came together pretty quickly. On my first pass of the grid, I had only filled in POLS, OPS, STARS, NO ME GUSTA and STEM. 5 answers and I was only confident in one!! The SE corner was the first to fill in for me, and it started with I GOTTA JET. It’s another common phrase  in my household. In the SW I had 30D as “I don’t know” which gave me wAldo as the world traveler 🤣 I had STARS but then removed it for my wrong guess down before ultimately putting it back in. cafe LATTE before ICED LATTE. hOnk at before TOOTED. orb spider before SPIDER-MAN. The list goes on and on. So many misdirects, but sleeping helped me cross the finish line. Final entry was fixing my fat finger typo of FEARySOnE to FEARSOME. 😆
Hard earned gold star today! 😅🤩

Beautiful, tough Saturday puzzle.

Some random thoughts:

I was mildly shocked (in a good way?) when SCREW THAT fell into place.  (Will the emus let me quote from the puzzle?)

In my house, "hit the car's horn" is "honked".  TOOTED is reserved for a less savory practice, that I'm too polite to mention.

A rare opportunity to be grateful to our current POTUS.  Thanks to his tariffs, TRADE WARS was close to being a gimme for me.

Put in HOot before HO HO, and spent a few precious moments wondering about the owl that (famously?) went around the world.

I'm curious about STALE BEER as a cure for a hangover.  Does one shake up a fresh beer to get rid of the carbonation, or does one drink the beer from the half-drunk leftovers of yesterday's party?

I loved (in a sad way) the T.S. ELIOT quotation.  The Philo in me wanted to put in Nietzsche, but he didn't fit, alas.

I'm tempted to put in a list of the words, phrases, and name that I didn't know before today, but the list would be quite long.  I'll only mention the interesting ECHOISM.  
I know I'm supposed to be happy to "learn" so much while doing a crossword, but I'm too painfully aware of how little of this will stick to call it a learning experience.

Unlike many people I don't have an electron microscope in amongst my ratchet wrenches and screwdrivers and have never used one, and the only "CSA" I know of is the one that used to exist in my part of the country in the 1860s, so that "C" was the last thing to fall. "OSMIC" just sounded right. I was still surprised to hear the music on my first guess, though. I had expected to be running the alphabet and just living with the dishonor.

Not a clean solve by a long shot, but I was surprised I got as much of it as I did without assistance. MENOMOSSO, for instance, actually came to me out of nowhere, as did several others that it seemed like I had no way of knowing. Kind of spooky in a way.

This one was hard for me, but that's what Saturday puzzles are supposed to be.
@Deb Amlen in the first tricky answer in your column, it should be TRADE WARS (plural) 😉

Contrary to popular opinion, this was a great, challenging Saturday. How Saturdays are supposed to be. The northeast was very hard and I needed some help but was able to solve the rest after much erasing.
Clever cluing, appropriately difficult for a Saturday, and oh so satisfying to complete!  Looking forward to more open grids from Ms. Hoody.

Re: CSA

A farm clue, here today for the ninth time, replaced the other clue five years ago. Here are the first and last:

Sun Nov 1, 2020	
56D
Farm-to-table program, in brief	
Julian Lim	
Shortz

Sun Jul 26, 2020	
94A	
Civil War side: Abbr. 	
Trenton Charlson	
Shortz

It's been a while since a Saturday puzzle has really put a scare in me. This one was absolutely brutal! It brought me back to my early days of puzzling when I'd tentatively fill in the last letter of the puzzle and was shocked to find that I'd actually solved it! I stumbled on the same words everyone else seemed to stumble on but I felt the puzzle was fair overall. Thank goodness for that one year of college Italian to point me in the right direction on MENO MOSSO or I never would have finished!

It seems this was a very hard puzzle for many people. Global Stats Difficulty Very Hard Median Solve Time 23:26 Median Solver 29% slower ⚡18% of users solved faster than their Saturday average. 5% solved much faster (>20%) than their Saturday average. 🐢82% of users solved slower than their Saturday average. 61% solved much slower (>20%) than their Saturday average. https://xwstats.com/puzzles/2025-09-20

Want to know what a SEMITONE sound like? Let György Ligeti, and Pierre-Laurent Aimard demonstrate--in this case an E-sharp to F-sharp--sadly, rigidly, and ceremoniously:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wIDN_3EkWN8&list=RDwIDN_3EkWN8&start_radio=1 What is a CSA? I know I could Duck-duck-go this, but I'd rather have a fellow commenter wordsplain it for me.
So hard! So good! I really enjoyed keeping at this one. It was TRADE WARS that finally cracked the NW.
Even with a leg up from the only T.S. Eliot quote I know, this was a tough one!  But not as tough as yesterday.  Please let tomorrow be a smooth solve.
Tough one. Found it hard to get a toehold. Even once I did each quadrant was its own challenge. Excellent Saturday puzzle.
Very tough.  I thought there was a lot of slang in this one too.  IGOTTAJET?  Farmer's market alternative is CSA? Very challenging.  Nervous about Sunday now!!

Very fun puzzle — just crunchy enough to feel like a Saturday (and on a lovely grid, btw), but the toughest entries were eminently solvable from crosses that involved only wordplay (i.e. no Naticks for the patient solver).

Personally favorite entries: SCREWTHAT! and KINGME!

Thanks, Katie!
Way too hard for me
Struggled, filled in the clues given to us, figured I would trundle along, had to reveal IGOTTOJET and realized this is not my puzzle.
Excellent—osmic, menomosso. I love a challenge!
This was impossible until it wasn't. Great Saturday puzzle!

I resented this puzzle when I read through it and could NOT ANSWER ONE SINGLE CLUE.  NOT ONE.  Leaving this one to the NYT crossword cult. 

But humiliating ordinary humans who have the temerity to attempt a Saturday crossword can't be good for expanding NYT readership.
54 down farmer's market alternative is CSA????  The only CSA I know of is the one seven of my great-great-granddads fought for in the 1860s (my eighth great-great-granddad fought against it.).

This was everything a Saturday puzzle should be: difficult, but not unfair. Several words I didn't know, but a bunch of ones I did, so it all worked out!

Me gusta!

I loved this crunchy Saturday puzzle! I had almost nothing on my first pass. And my second revealed only an entry or two. On my third pass, a few squares filled in by deductive reasoning on the word patterns. Then, very slowly but surely, it all came together. Just perfect! Funny, my first thought on 1A was indeed the answer, but I thought, [no way in hell] could that be it. A few downs proved me wrong (or right, as it turned out!)

This brought back a memory from college. Someone in the lab was studying grunion and wanted eggs stained for electron microscopy. My professor stressed that the osmium tetroxide I would be using was highly toxic so I had to use the fume hood. By the time we got back from the beach, after the grunion run, it was after midnight. Everyone left and I preserved and stained the eggs, very carefully! After all that, I never got to see the results. I was just a lab technician. This experience didn’t help me solve the puzzle, though, as I never heard it called OSMIC acid.

The theme for this puzzle should have been SCREWTHAT!

What a heaping pile💩 

I don’t think I’ve ever seen so many one or two word clues that led to answers that were sometimes made up by the constructor.  

This was not clever, wasn’t interesting, it was extremely challenging, but that doesn’t make it a good puzzle.

As my Granny used to say, "Lordy mussy!"  (Eventually I translated this..."Lord have mercy." )  Either will do.  GOTTA trot that out for this hornswoggler of a puzzle, I must say.  

I had a misleading good start--KING ME!  TONS!  SMOKE RING! MONSOON!..and then TOOT AT (arrgh)...TIGHTER!....RATS NEST doesn't begin to describe it...  I inched my way along, giving the pen's eraser a good work-out.  I had WELD and took it out because nothing else worked.  And so it went.

I still do not "get" ST LEO...neither the uni nor the home town.  
And a third baseman Bohm....  mean, mean, mean.
60A and 38D (MENO MOSSO and ECHOISM) were behond the pale.  (DHubby is a psychologist and personalities were a big focus for his work... he's never heard this term.  Just sayin'...)

Remember the Opium War? Now that was a proper TRADE WAR.
China: Stop selling drugs to our people!
England: Make me! And we'll have Hong Kong, while we're at it. Wouldn't be a problem if your people didn't want the drugs so much.
Does any of this sound familiar?

Great paté, Mom, but I GOTTA JET if I want to be ready for that funeral.
This was a hard puzzle. That’s all.
Can someone explain the wood/charcoal media one?!
Well this was humbling.

Suspect this puzzle was aimed at the older generation.
Very difficult but not that fun for me.
Nothing felt rewarding about it.
Probably need years of puzzle doing to get they joy that a relatively miniscule number of commenters are reporting.
Relieved that at least today, the overall vibe here is that this was for the harcore folk.

I made it through. That’s all that can be said. It wasn’t enjoyable at all. I don’t mind difficult puzzles.

I looked at it last night and had hardly anything. Then, this morning, somehow I saw TRADEWARS. It began to feel from there. The southeast corner was nuts.
I had to give up…snif. Too many clues I was utterly dumbfounded by. When FEARSOME was used for “Chilling’, I left the puzzle. Saturday is always the hardest for me, I’m better but still struggle.

Felt like a proper Saturday puzz to me! A few fills on the first pass then things started randomly falling into place. Not sure if it’s an age thing. Is this the same Gary Larson who does the Far Side comics?

It seems to me that the phrase "I GOTTA JET" means "I have to leave quickly" and is inspired by leaving on a jet plane. Now jet planes work (by the definition of the word "jet") using the equal and opposite reaction (thrust) from emitting a stream of heated fluid. I can thus see how a clue like [Later!] could also be a good clue for "I gotta squirt" but that's left for a future constructor.

Even as I protest the mendacious propaganda purporting to a dilution of the Gray Lady's grid, it seems:

The trend toward crosswords with legs  has created more success using one's brain, not the dictionary.  Mr Shortz & CO secure the future solver's ability to enjoy a day like today, any day.

Esoterica and topicality are passe. We may not be around to wonder at the shaking heads bemused by our flexing - but no? If in doubt, try a crossword puzzle from the 70s - good gravy!

Any keyboard character, animation and grid construct is open for exploration, exploitation and edification,

A rebus is the final frontier separating the casual guest and determined enthusiast,

And . . .

Nothing beats that lightning-quick synaptic snap of delight when solving a head scratcher like today's crossword puzzle!

Working tough puzzles is how you get better. It's how you got to where you are, but you can't just coast on your laurels, and you should never blame a failure on the people who unveiled your nemesis.

@Mean Old Lady

My wife was born in Atlanta, and her mother and her kin on her mother's side were sharecroppers in rural Georgia and Kentucky during the Depression (including a great-uncle who used to take his fiddle with him and ride the rails after the crops were in every year). @CJ - Do you not prepare and stain your own samples? 

I did quite a lot of EM back in the day, and OSMIC acid, lead citrate,  and uranyl acetate were the most common stains for most biological material. OSMIC acid was also a fixative. 

The advantage of OSMIC acid was that it helped to visualize cellular membranes, since it stained the fatty acids in phospholipids. 

Granted, these are hazardous materials, so maybe things have changed -- what do you stain your tissues with so that they are can be visualized under the EM?

@MmmmHmm

So I really do understand your frustration. But it really does take practice, being open to all kinds of knowledge, and hard work to be up to a Saturday—and to start off you could try Googling a few answers and seeing where you go from there. But Saturday crosswords may not be for you. The newspapers used to publish a Bridge column. To appreciate it you had to understand bridge and also be pretty good at it. It wasn’t for everyone. And admittedly eventually it went away because not enough people played bridge (which may be part of your point). But for now lots of people can and do solve and enjoy difficult puzzles. I hope you can run with it and use it to expand your horizons—or not if you decide it’s really not your thing.

First off, thank you for ending your comment on a positive note! I am an inveterate critic of all things human myself, but I strongly believe in giving credit where it’s due.

“Too many "know it or you don't" references and trivia, mixed with clueing that has too many valid responses to choose from”
